text: Patient: I can’t think of anything. Did you go to M___? Doctor: I went to ____ in M___. Patient: Okay, I see the gold and blue socks. Doctor: Oh no, I had an orange shirt on, so I put on orange socks. Patient: Okay, a maze of blue. Patient: Bless you! Doctor: Now the first-in-human study, I don’t think you’re eligible for it because of the liver. They only want bone disease. Uh- A lot of paperwork you’ve got read. Patient: Yeah, I hear that. Doctor: You can check with Dr. G___ Any notes from us - So let’s get a hold of your results from your most recent lung scan and your visit from pulmonology as to what they say or their thinking is behind your gasping spells. It’s important. Ah, your ARV7 is positive. That suggests that the Enzalutamide may not work very long. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s likely in the near future that you’ll need new belly scan, abdominal scan, bone scan for us to more directly determine that the Enzalutamide is not benefiting you. So we tried to get your tissue sent for molecular testing but when we sent it, it wasn’t adequate for that sort of evaluation, so Dr. G__ may look at other options. Sometimes they can do another biopsy or do a blood test, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: but that’s not as good, but it’s something that’s easy, though. So once we’ve determined that your cancer has continued to grow, the standard therapy would be to move you to chemotherapy and if the name docetaxel based chemotherapy. Alternatively we’ve got two studies. I got rid of one as I wrote that.

text: Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and then we check you for a period of a year because we want to know. Same thing like the flu shot is only good for a finite time, right, like this much time is in it. Well, we know every year you have to re-up on that flu shot. We have no idea about this medicine. It’s a one and done. So, our patient’s sign up for, hey I wonder what’s going on in nine months or a year after the fact. So, we hope you participate in that because it’s important for us to know so that’s one treatment option. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: Now, after we do that, a month after that I rescan you again because by then it’s already about ten, twelve weeks that’s passed, almost three months, and then we see what the scans are when they’re done; if they’re worse, the same, or sort of the same. So, that’s all your two choices. Um, and if it’s not or if your PSA is now going whoa, it’s really up there, we normally then will say okay, we either got to commit to chemo Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or pills. Now, chemo and pills are FDA approved. Kind of just like when you had the chemo before Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: FDA approved. We would do a different chemo. I wouldn’t repeat the same chemo but it’s a cousin drug so it’s still once every three weeks just like before. Okay, the pills are four pills a day every day. Patient: For the rest of your life? Doctor: Yeah, until it stops working, which at some point after a couple years it sort of poops out and stops working. So, we have studies there too. So, you got to say okay, what’s this study with the chemo. Well, you know in Oncology we love to combine stuff so the study is either the pill or chemo plus the pill. I know. So, it’s a win-win in the sense that you either get the pill get the pill that you were going to get anyways Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or you actually get the double whammy and you get the pill and Patient: and the chemo.

text: Patient: Well, will they tell you, uh, if I went down there and spent a couple of days and had the testing done-. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Will they tell you, uh, if it’s needed? Would they tell if it’s needed or not in lieu of that? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Because I can ask. They won’t show me the films, but they have a special radiologist read it, and they come back to me and tell me if you are likely to go on the study or not. Because if your cancer doesn’t have that antigen, it’s pointless to go on the medication. Patient: Right. It can’t- Doctor: So then we wouldn’t move forward with the treatment. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh and then they pretty much send you home. Um and they, they’ve been treating about every two months, so. Patient: So then you go back again? Doctor: Potentially, yeah. Patient: Potentially? Doctor: I know they’ve done uh I want to say up to four treatments I’ve seen at the most for every two months or so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They, they uh, I don’t think they’ve worked out totally the scheme of what’s the best way to do it, every two months at most it’s been. Each center does it slightly different. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh but that’s, that’s about what they do. Uh I’m not really sure because they haven’t seen profound bone marrow effects. One of the problems with radioactive things is you can get- Patient: Sure. Um hum. Doctor: Injury to the bone marrow. My experience with them is that particularly with patients who’ve had, not had a lot of chemotherapy, so not a lot of things to injure the bone marrow, they don’t seem to really have a problem with bone marrow toxicity from this study.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: and you may opt out. For example, if you had say I just want to focus on treating that area let’s just do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: now one of the things that about the trial is that it’s randomized. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: What does a randomized trial mean and in this particular case what are people are being randomized too. Randomized means that a computer and then essentially flips a coin and is random, very random in group A and group B of the clinical trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So in this study there is a random allocation of the therapy and random also means that neither the physician which is me nor the patient which is you knows So it truly is random. And also the computer program flips the coin so to speak, you can only flip it once, you can’t continue to flip over and over until you get the condition you want Patient: Okay. Doctor: So option one is what we call observation. Your option two is the stereotactic radiotherapy, which I mentioned is called SBRT for short. that in order to make this trial a little more attractive to patients is designed ins such a way that the odds of getting the radiotherapy are twice as high as the odds of getting the observation. So in other words, you can think of it as a three-headed coin, there’s a one out of three chance that you’re gonna get the observation group. That’s about a thirty-three percent chance. And there’s a two out of three chance or sixty-six percent that you will get the stereotactic radiotherapy which most people on this trial want to get. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it.

Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it.

Healthcare Professional: So we just need to do a date clarification 'cause- so the pharmacy can use the last order the last time. Just have to change today’s date, so.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
